data.text: Where Have You Met the Nicest People on a Bike Tour
In your experience touring though out the world, where have you met the nicest people?
For my current tour around Europe since one year, I would say Poland and Turkey (even it is not totally in Europe)
data.author: Florian Magnien

data.author: Andrew Moody

data.text: I used to think the nice people I met were purely regional. "oh that happened bc I was in such in such place" etc.. but the more I ride, the more I truly believe there's a thing I'm calling "tour magic" and people are genuinely nicer to people on bike tours. They're either curious about it and excited to ask questions or they've done it before and want to cheer you on. Returning home from a trip to my native Brooklyn... a man stopped us on the Manhattan Bridge to ask us if we needed a place to stay because it was late. He rode past us...then circled back specifically to come check on us. Bike people are nice people
data.author: Lindsey Hamma

data.text: i would say there are nice ppl everywhere. In fact most ppl are nice. However, when you pass through slowly, spend time in, a place the locals appreciate your openness and willingness to not just rush by....

data.author: Catherine Racicot

data.text: I did most of my touring pre 9-11 in the US, but I think everyone is pretty much nice to cyclist. Other than the odd idiot, I did have someone discharge a pistol(?) next to me as I was ridding in Florida, and had a few things thrown at me from time to time, I'm sure the guy near Sparta Tenn was just trying to cool me off with the full cup of soda hit me in the back... But I've had people go out of their way for me every where. Canal inspector opened a gate so I could camp along a canal in NH, riding late along the St Lawrence Sea Way I had a guy call me over to his porch, let me stay in his garden, fed me dinner and gave me a bunch of fruit to take with me. Had a Black Hwy patrol officer suggest I needed to cycle out of a rural Alabama area because of the rural people there. A mile or 2 down the road I got invited to a BBQ as I rode by. Later suggested where I could camp a few miles down the road. Best is still the Pharmacist who to picked me up during a light sprinkle with wicker furniture in the back of his Pickup of Natchez Trace as I was pushing my bike toward town having just ripped the sidewall of my tire. I had a foldable and was just looking for a dry area to put it on. He picked me up. Took me to pickup tires and then to a friends garage so I could use a bike stand. Took me home kicked his teen age daughter out of her room to give me a place to stay. Then wouldn't let me ride back to the Trace in the morning, insisting on driving me back.... All he got was a few tales of my adventures...

data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: I too have toured about 10,000 miles in the US, 14 different states, and another 5,000 miles in Canada and Europe (10 countries) and the only place I have had cars pass way too close, the only place I have had people shout at me to get off the road out their car window is in the good old USA.
data.author: Don Millikin

data.text: have had the best and worst experience's in the USA. But thinking about it only 2 bad incidents but many good ones

data.text: if you're ever near me, please don't ask me to host. I don't get paid to host and most people have told me how they appreciate being hosted. If it's not appreciated, why bother.
data.author: Mike Kwan

data.text: I think you may have misunderstood my post, I did not mean to infer that everyone in the USA is a dick, it is just that the only place I encountered any dicks was in the USA; maybe a dozen in 10,000 miles, everyone else have been great, and much appreciated.
data.author: Don Millikin

data.text: I traveled the contiguous perimeter of the US. I wrote a book about my interactions with people. In one sentence, here, I‚Äôd say that the regional reactions did differ, and were interesting, but everywhere people were mostly generous, open, eager to give, and share their stories with the cyclist passing through.

Not sure I'd want to cycle travel in Liberia or DRC, but the people were great there, too. :)
data.author: Kathy Norton

data.text: People respond to people...if you are open to hearing people's story and are truly curious...People respond the genuine openness that you bring to them and their situation. Relationships are reciprocal, the minute to minute small encounters on a bike trip while you are passing through town are represented in the way you carry yourself and interact. Smile and the world smiles with you.
data.author: Joanne Mitchell

data.text: I haven‚Äôt been there but for many years I have consistently read that Iranians are unbelievably friendly and welcoming. Apparently cars constantly stop to talk to bicycle and motorcycle travellers. In my experience the Balkan countries were by far the least friendly but haven‚Äôt been there for many years. Turkey, Japan, New Zealand amongst many friendly and welcoming countries I‚Äôve been to.

data.text: Every where. There is always an awesome person you meet along the way. Biggest smiles and friendliest greeting to everyone and anyone would have to be Fiji! Bula Vinaka! Tourism Fiji
data.author: Steph Godsiff

data.text: You are probably quite right about Fiji. My near brother-in-law, Jack, has been there twice, cycling. And the Fijian people were super nice and very friendly. He would always carry a big bag of rice so if he got caught and had to stay for dinner he would have food to contribute to the feast. I remember a story from my sister, about Jack saying that they have to be really pick up the pace as they were coming up on the village on a bit of an uphill climb. Jack is a a very kind soul and if a village elder stop them he wouldn't be rude and he carried the rice because these people are not wealth. I met my first Fijian on my second tour of New Zealand (north Island) in Whangarei. It was an incredible positive experience and kava ceremony was involved. I went to this substantially an outdoor pub for a wood fired pizza and a beer (German Alt style) and I left with a very fond memory that I will never forget and it was all instigated by this one Fijian. He treated me as one would a close friend. It started with the Fijian, the pub owner/manager, this quiet respectful Maori (I really liked him) and, then, me. When I left, there was a whole lot of people crowded around our table. Your comment triggered that memory and the writing of this, brought the memory flooding back into clear focus. Thanks.
data.author: Hermann Kerr

data.text: I love this story! Haha..and I know Whangarei...live an hour North.
data.author: Steph Godsiff

data.text: I cycled through your hood, Paihia, when I was there in 2012. I only took three pictures there but I got a few more from, close by, Russel which I liked. What I remember about Paihai most was a vendor on the beach, and it turns out we had a connection through an New Zealander expat who now lives in Clayoquot Sound, John Dowd and (Kiwi) ocean kayaker extraordinaire.

data.author: Shannon Burleigh

data.text: I found the friendliest people were in places where fewer cyclists were out on the roads! I got the most hospitality offers in USA..My favorite was Colorado. I'd park my bike to go food shopping, or stop to take a photo, and people would walk up to me, fascinated by a single woman carrying so much stuff on a bike...they'd stop to chat and end up offering their yard or a guest room fir the night! Sometimes I had multiple offers in a day lol. I had a hard time meeting people in Europe, I guess too many other cyclists so they weren't fascinated with my journey lol

data.text: Java, Indonesia
data.author: Shane Adams

data.text: Iran. The first thing that happened to me there was that I bought some food from a small store, and sat down on the bench outside to eat it. The very same guy who sold the food to me was like "no no no, you can not eat here. My wife has just made lunch. You shall come with me and eat lunch at our house". Then it all continued like that for the duration of my stay.
data.author: Wilhelm Mellerg√•rd

data.text: One consequence of my (mostly) TransAm tour in 1982 is that the good people of Kansas have a special place in my heart. Upon riding into a small town in Kansas one evening, a guy on his day off stopped his pickup to tell me that he was headed over to the pool to open it up so I could use the shower. Where I live, I can‚Äôt possibly imagine that any city employee would care enough to do this for a stranger, while on their day off of work. A wheat farmer lectured me about the importance of parity pricing. I admired him taking the long view on educating one voter at a time on an issue of vital importance to him. When I was coming out of a grocery store, a farmer asked me where I was from. When I replied, ‚ÄúCalifornia‚Äù he curiously asked, ‚ÄúCalifornia? What do they grow there?‚Äù
data.author: Gordon Hamachi

data.text: Is it weird if I say I tour to avoid people? Ive turned down offers to stay at people's houses and meal and stuff. I tour to go out camping in the woods alone, not to socialize. Although I'm grateful when people to offer hospitality, even if I don't accept it.
